body.p: An overheating engine can quickly cause serious damage to a car, and therefore a dashboard red warning light is supposed to come on if that happens. In a certain model car, there is a 3% chance of the engine overheating (event H). The probability of the warning light showing up (event W) when it should (i.e., when the engine is really overheating) is 0.98, however, 1% of the time the warning light appears for no apparent reason (i.e., when the engine temperature is normal).
In an activity in the previous part we identified the information that this problem provides:
Which of the following is a correct representation of the given information in a probability tree?

response.feedback: Incorrect. The problem with this tree is the probabilities in the two second branch-offs. Note, for example, that we are given that P(W | H) = .98, and according to your tree, it is .99. Also, we are given that P(W | not H) is .01, and according to your tree it is .98.

Incorrect. While you were right to choose a tree that depicts the fact that H occurs naturally before W, your probabilities are incorrect. Note that P(H) = .03 and not .98 as your tree suggests. (.98 is P(W | H), and should appear in the second branch-off.). Also, note that the probabilities of the first two branches do not sum to 1 as they should.

Incorrect. While the probabilities are in the right place, you are mixing up the events H (engine overheating) and W (warning light shows up). Note that the natural order is that first H happens and then W. According to the tree you chose, W happens before H.

Good job! Note that the tree you chose depicts the fact that the natural order is that H happens first (engine overheats), and then W (warning light shows up). The probabilities of each branch are also correct, starting with the non-conditional probabilities for the first branch-off, and conditional probabilities for the second branch-off, making sure that the probabilities of branches branching off the same point add up to 1.
